comment: Converted inline list to a bullet list in opening.

diff.*:
Line 4: Line 4:  
'''Ethics''' (also known as '''moral philosophy''') is a branch of [[philosophy]] which seeks to address questions about [[morality]]; that is, about concepts like [[good]] and [[bad]], [[right]] and [[wrong]], [[justice]], [[virtue]], etc.
 
'''Ethics''' (also known as '''moral philosophy''') is a branch of [[philosophy]] which seeks to address questions about [[morality]]; that is, about concepts like [[good]] and [[bad]], [[right]] and [[wrong]], [[justice]], [[virtue]], etc.
    −
Major branches of ethics include [[meta-ethics]], about the theoretical meaning and reference of moral propositions and how their [[truth-value]]s (if any) may be determined; [[normative ethics]], about the practical means of determining a moral course of action; [[applied ethics]], about how moral outcomes can be achieved in specific situations; [[moral psychology]], about how moral capacity or moral agency develops and what its nature is; and [[descriptive ethics]], about what moral values people actually abide by. Within each of these branches are many different schools of thought and still further sub-fields of study.
+
Major branches of ethics include:
  +
* [[meta-ethics]], about the theoretical meaning and reference of moral propositions and how their [[truth-value]]s (if any) may be determined;
  +
* [[normative ethics]], about the practical means of determining a moral course of action;
  +
* [[applied ethics]], about how moral outcomes can be achieved in specific situations;
  +
* [[moral psychology]], about how moral capacity or moral agency develops and what its nature is; and
  +
* [[descriptive ethics]], about what moral values people actually abide by.
  +   +
Within each of these branches are many different schools of thought and still further sub-fields of study.
     
==Meta-ethics==
 
==Meta-ethics==
